>>17509673
>>17509691
> I mean to say, at least move on to something more interesting. If you go through Nietzsche as a stage that is understandable, but staying there is kind of embarrassing if you're older than 25.

The juvenile readings of Nietzsche are only an aspect of his philosphy, and do not truly grasp him. It is like those who thought the point of Fight Club was to fight and destroy shit. Nietzsche had inspired some of the greatest thinkers and artists of the 20th century. These people were not stupid nor juvenile.
The juvenile readings are often not wrong, but just limited. His writings often have multiple meanings, so even if you have a reading that is not wrong per se, it doesn't mean it's the whole truth. I've seen it before also with a christcuck on this board who had a valid perspective on will to power, but absolutely seethed at the idea that there was more to it than his interpretation, because all he wanted to do was to "refute", as if refutation of a philosophy of the kind that Nietzsche writes is even possible.

An example of what I'm thinking of is the concept of the Overman from TSZ. The juvenile reading of the Overman is individualistic, might is right, egoist. This is not necessarily a wrong interpretation, but it is the least interesting, in my opinion. The Overman is also a social idea, the idea that the meaning of humanity can be achieved by emergence, that humanity can justify itself by achieving something beyond itself. The Overman is the antithesis to the Last Man. It is an imperative, a call to action that is both social and personal, to strive to create meaning, purpose, life, both for ourselves as persons and as a society. It is fundamentally a call to struggle agaisnt the forces of nihilism and despair. If you only focus on the juvenile interpration, you lose this understanding of Overman.

The thing is, there is a fundametal tension in most of what Nietzsche writes between romanticism and cynicism, nihilism and anti-nihilism, etc. I think this is well encapsulated in his short essay 'On the Pathos of Truth', where he displays his ability to earnestly produce two well-argumented positions in direct opposition to each other. This is also why much of his writing is so fascinating. And finally, this is why it is very possible to read and learn from Nietzsche, even as a Christian. He has much to teach, and much to inspire Christians with. I'm sure many Christians have done so. But to do that, you'd have to approach him in good faith. Most christcucks immediatly think the equivalent of ORANGE BAD MAN when his name is brought up, probably because they've always been Christians and someone once told them that Nietzsche was the great atheist philosopher or something, and thus they decided to hate him, without knowing him.

I don't enjoy Evola or Foucault, so no to then. But definitely yes to the others. Even if people like Baudrillard and Land can be nonsensical, they also have novel and interesting perspectives. Jünger is a good writer, I love Storm of Steel. Weber has similarities to Schmitt, I actually think he's better. He sees the essential aspects and explicates them. This is much of his inheritance from Nietzsche, along with his understanding of power. His explication of the idealtypical method for example, or his famous definition of the state. He also has a somewhat coherent system of thought, which is kind of rare, especially give the breadth of his writing.

name: Real OP
com: >>17510982

name: Anonymous
com:
Don't think Shakespeare would be adequate.
I've never really knuckled down and studied this shit, but if I were to do so, I'd split it into these broad phases.
From the English perspective, you've got
-The pre Alfred the Great days, pre unification of England, ie the heptarchy.
-From Alfred the Great to the defeat of Harold Godwinson by William the Conqueror.
-From William the Conqueror to the Battle of Bosworth and the accession of Henry VII.
-From Henry VIII and the Reformation, to their consequences in the following century (the personal union of the Kingdoms of Scotland and England, the Wars of the Three Kingdoms (the other being Ireland), of which the English Civil War was the main, the regicide of Charles I, Cromwell's Commonwealth interregnum, the Restoration, then the Glorious Revolution.
-The Jacobite Uprisings of the Stuart Pretenders were kinda aftershocks from that, but given they failed, I think the Glorious Revolution marks one of the last major cut-off points and honestly there's not been any significant shift in direction since then.

As you can probably tell, I'm most read on the 16th and 17th centuries, although personally the 15th century is immensely interesting. It was the last century where a lot of stuff was still up in the air and there were a lot of what-ifs, what if the Wars of the Roses had gone differently, what if certain people hadn't met untimely deaths, what if Edward IV had supported the Black Douglas' and MacDonalds in Scotland etc.

Henry VIII was a self-centred, incompetent, fat buffoon who ruined everything and our history has been pretty much railroaded since.

name: Real OP
com:
>>17511047
Impressive autism, writing that long diatribe. You still haven't answered my question though. Any good books on English history that you would recommend?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17511131
No
>I've never really knuckled down and studied this shit

I've given you the broad outlines to search for your own reading material. I wouldn't trust anything so broadly focused on the entire history of the monarchs of these isles.
You can decide to read chronologically or not. Like, the Norman Conquest was a pretty damn hard break so you don't necessarily need to read about earlier Anglo-Saxon rule beforehand, only if you're interested in shit like the heptarchy, Danelaw etc.
Similarly, Henry VIII and the Reformation were a pretty hard break where you'd still be able to orient yourself without reading about prior shit.
But honestly I'd be inclined to at least read from Henry VIII to contextualise everything up to the current day.

Just search for books yourself it shouldn't be that hard.

name: Anonymous
com:
My dear Russell,

I didn’t like your letter. What’s the good of living as you do, anyway. I don’t believe your lectures are good. They are nearly over, aren’t they?

What’s the good of sticking in the damned ship and haranguing the merchant-pilgrims in their own language. Why don’t you drop overboard? Why don’t you clear out of the whole show?

One must be an outlaw these days, not a teacher or preacher. One must retire out of the herd & then fire bombs into it. You said in your lecture on education that you didn’t set much count by the unconscious. That is sheer perversity. The whole of the consciousness and the conscious content is old hat—the millstone round your neck.

Do cut it—cut your will and leave your old self behind. Even your mathematics are only dead truth: and no matter how fine you grind the dead meat, you’ll not bring it to life again.

Do stop working & writing altogether and become a creature instead of a mechanical instrument. Do clear out of the whole social ship. Do for your very pride’s sake become a mere nothing, a mole, a creature that feels its way & doesn’t think. Do for heavens sake be a baby, & not a savant any more. Don’t do anything any more—but for heavens sake begin to be—start at the very beginning and be a perfect baby: in the name of courage.

Oh, and I want to ask you, when you make your will, do leave me enough to live on. I want you to live forever. But I want you to make me in some part your heir.

We have got to clear out of this house in a week’s time. We are looking for another house. You had better come & live near us : but not if you are going to be a thinker and a worker, only if you are going to be a creature, an infant …

My love to you. Stop working and being an ego, & have the courage to be a creature.

Yours,
Sneed. H. Lawrence

name: Anonymous
com:
>Your ideal is a purely negative one, absence of suffering, which can be completely secured by non-existence. I, on the other hand, have positive ideals: I admire Alcibiades, and the Emperor Frederick II, and Napoleon. For the sake of such men, any misery is worth while. I appeal to You, Lord, as the greatest of creative artists, do not let Your artistic impulses be curbed by the degenerate fear-ridden maunderings of this wretched psychopath."
>Buddha, who in the courts of Heaven has learnt all history since his death, and has mastered science with delight in the knowledge and sorrow at the use to which men have put it, replies with calm urbanity:
>"You are mistaken, Professor Nietzsche, in thinking my ideal a purely negative one. True, it includes a negative element, the absence of suffering; but it has in addition quiet as much that is positive as it to be found in your doctrine. Though I have no special admiration for Alcibiades and Napoleon, I, too, have my heroes: my successor Jesus, because he told men to love their enemies; the men who discovered how to master the forces of nature and secure food with less labour; the medical men who have shown how to diminish disease; the poets and artists and musicians who have caught glimpses of the Divine beatitude. Love and knowledge and delight in beauty are not negations; they are enough to fill the lives of the greatest men that have ever lived."
>"All the same," Nietzsche replies, "your world would be insipid. You should study Heraclitus, whose works survive complete in the celestial library. Your love is compassion, which is elicited by pain; your truth, if you are honest, is unpleasant, and only to be known through suffering; and as to beauty, what is more beautiful than the tiger, who owes his splendour to his fierceness? No, if the Lord should decide for your world, I fear we would all die of boredom." "You might," Buddha replies, "because you love pain, and your love of life is a sham. But those who really love life would be happy as no one can be happy in the world as it is."
>For my part, I agree with Buddha as I have imagined him. But I do not know how to prove that he is right by any argument such as can be used in a mathematical or a scientific question. I dislike him Nietzsche because he likes the contemplation of pain, because he erects conceit into a duty, because the men whom he most admires are conquerors, whose glory is cleverness in causing men to die. But I think the ultimate argument against his philosophy, as against any unpleasant but internally self-consistent ethic, lies not in an appeal to facts, but in an appeal to emotions. Nietzsche despises universal love; I feel it the motive power to all that I desire as regards the world. His followers have had their innings, but we may hope that it is coming rapidly to an end.

name: Anonymous
com: My habits are periodic ebbs and flows. For a few weeks I may not read at all. Then I find a decent book and get into a flow of reading hours daily. I may read 2 books at once but not more. Somehow after a bit, maybe as short as a week or as long as a couple months, after finishing 1-4 books, I just read less and less and then stop entirely. Usually I stop in the middle of a book, often one that isn't that great so I lose interest but don't start a new one. For instance in early January I went through Hillbilly Elegy, Crime and Punishment, and two thirds of the Possessed within a couple weeks. Then I got tired of so much Dosto (altho he's great) and didn't pick back up the Possessed until this week. Finished it, now churning through Democracy in America.

com:
>>17511172
the question itself doesn't even make any sense - to christians, god is identified with goodness itself, to secularists, there is no god and what they think of as "goodness" is what defines their belief system. so either there is no difference, or it doesn't matter - there's no system of belief where those two things (commandments from god and moral prerogatives) both exist as distinct but meaningfully commensurable terms
the confusion i think arises from the fact that these two systems aren't logical formalities that you can analyze independently. they actually form the terms by which all other moral thoughts can be expressed, and whichever set of terms you use to define the world (secular terms, of "goodness" in the abstract, or christian terms, of god and the law) is the system in which any possible comparison can take place. that's why absurdities arise when you try to compare them - you can compare terms in a belief system with each other, but you can't really express belief systems in terms of each other without ending up with patently ridiculous nonsense like "akshually god is a huge jerk because he killed a bunch of people and is also a sexist"
the only reason anybody even gets the idea that you can actually meaningfully compare those two things is because people often are secularists without actually knowing they are - they think they believe in god, but really they believe in something else, to which any subsequent belief systems (like christianity) are subordinate. then, since of course jesus said things that do not agree with secularism, they must do work to unify their beliefs into a coherent whole, and so end up judging one system (christianity) by the other (secularism). but this doesn't make them in the least bit christian - if they were christian, they would judge secularism by christian terms, not christianity by secular terms
this is pretty much the only way that secular "goodness" and christian "god" coexist under the same system of beliefs, but the resulting system contains only secular terms, and only what secularism thinks of as "good" - it is secularism! it is completely unrelated to any christian sense of "goodness", because it had to pass through secularism first, and so was redefined by and into secular terms
if you don't like the word "secularism" please replace it with any other synonym for modern western liberal morality, i'm sure you can think of plenty

name: Anonymous

>>17511885
Argumentum Ornithologicum

I close my eyes and see a flock of birds. The vision lasts a second or perhaps less; I don’t know how many birds I saw. Were they a definite or an indefinite number? This problem involves the question of the existence of God. If God exists, the number is definite, because how many birds I saw is known to God. If God does not exist, the number is indefinite, because nobody was able to take count. In this case, I saw fewer than ten birds (let’s say) and more than one; but I did not see nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, or two birds. I saw a number between ten and one, but not nine, eight, seven, six, five, etc. That number, as a whole number, is inconceivable; ergo, God exists.

Sadie
White coat
You carry me home
And bury this bone
And take this pinecone
Bury this bone
To gnaw on it later, gnawing on the telephone
Until then, we pray and suspend
The notion that these lives do never end
And all day long we talk about mercy
Lead me to water, Lord, I sure am thirsty
Down in the ditch where I nearly served you
Up in the clouds where he almost heard you
And all that we built
And all that we breathed
And all that we spilt
Or pulled up like weeds
Is piled up in back
And it burns irrevocably
We spoke up in turns
'Til the silence crept over me
And bless you
And I deeply do
No longer resolute
Oh, and I call to you
But the water got so cold
And you do lose
What you don't hold
This is an old song
These are old blues
And this is not my tune
But it's mine to use
And the seabirds
Where the fear once grew
Will flock with a fury
And they will bury
What'd come for you
And down where I darn with the milk-eyed mender
You and I, and a love so tender
Stretched on a hoop where I stitch this adage
Bless our house and its heart so savage
And all that I want
And all that I need
And all that I've got
Is scattered like seed
And all that I knew
Is moving away from me
And all that I know
Is blowing like tumbleweed
And the mealy worms
In the brine will burn
In a salty pyre
Among the fauns and ferns
And the love we hold
And the love we spurn
Will never grow cold
Only taciturn
And I'll tell you tomorrow
Oh Sadie, go on home now
And bless those who've sickened below
And bless us who have chosen so
And all that I've got
And all that I need
I tie in a knot
And I lay at your feet
And I have not forgot
But a silence crept over me
So dig up your bone
Exhume your pinecone, Sadie

name: Anonymous
com:
Solve et coagula, anon. Solve always comes before coagula. If the nature of the world and of knowledge of the world were ONLY solvere, there would be no force pulling you (even now) to some future coagulare.

What do you know? You know you're really in this bitch, you know you're you. You don't know what that you is, but you know it. You know that nothing in your ordinary knowledge is permanent, that when you doubt all the way down to the bottom, it's possible to find that there isn't even a bottom, that the essence of ordinary knowledge is movement and change, not stability. But certain things don't change. You are still there, even amidst all the movement with no stability. And you feel yourself pulled, even when posting this thread, to something beyond the flux, to some stability that doesn't dissolve, like all the ordinary bits of knowledge you have tried out so far.

What do you think inspired Socrates and Plato? Was it the natural philosophy or proto-science Anaxagoras or Thales? No, it was Heraclitus, because Heraclitus brought the problem of flux to its highest point, practically daring anyone who came after him to find a way to designate something stable in the flux, when even their very designations would have to take place WITHIN that flux, and thus could not be stable. That is why flux is a paradox. Socrates and Plato didn't retreat away from Heraclitus' articulation of flux as the only manifest fact of the world, they embraced it, but put emphasis on MANIFEST. I said above, "ordinary knowledge," not knowledge. The discovery of flux, of sceptical regress and free fall, is indeed a decisive blow to the stability of ordinary, manifest knowledge. And this discovery initially causes a feeling of vertigo. But instead of trying to retreat from the vertigo, Socrates and Plato observed that there are forces and inclinations still pulling on us even when we seem to doubt everything else. Even when we can't discursively demonstrate something with certainty, we have a priori ideas of certainty. Even when we can't discursively demonstrate morality, even when all of our inquiries into morality terminate in nihilism and aporia, we still feel a fragment of "the" moral within us.

The more we follow this fragment, which is not itself discursive but a sort of law or north star "governing" all of our particular, discursive articulations of it, the better, or more "adequate" our discursive articulations become, and the more we seem to feel and even see something behind and beyond the manifest and the ordinary.

Discursive knowledge is a tool. Even mathematical proofs are expressed in this language. Complacent minds never question the parameters or the "why" of their pre-give ntools. Slightly stronger minds realise the contingency of their tools but never seek beyond that, assuming the nature of nature is raw contingency. Wise minds ask "Who made the tools? In the image of what, or of whom, are the tools made?"

>Now we must ask: how is it with the position of the network of concepts in regard to super-sensible reality? When he, who through the methods of clairvoyance discloses the super-sensible reality, now approaches this reality with his concepts, he will thus find the network of concepts coincides just as much with the super-sensible world. From the other side the super-sensible reality throws its rays as it were on the network of concepts, as on the one side does the sensible reality.

>Now whence comes this network of concepts itself? Here that can only be asserted as fact, for the answer to this question can only result as the consequence of the logical path which we shall yet be able to take together. Today I will only give you a picture of this network of concepts, in order to show whence the network, which a man weaves within him, takes it origin. That is best made clear by a shadow picture. The shadow-picture of the hand would never arise if the hand were not there. The shadow-picture resembles its prototype, but it has one peculiarity! it is nothing! Through the fact that in the place of light the non-light comes, through the partial occluding of the light the shadow-picture comes into being. The concepts arise in exactly the same way, through the fact that behind our thinking soul there stands the super-sensible reality.

>The concepts also are really only an obliteration of the super-sensible reality, and because they resemble the spiritual world, as the shadow-pictures do the prototypes, for this reason the human being can form an inkling of the super-sensible worlds. When the perception of the super-sensible makes concept with the sensible, then these shadow-pictures arise. In the conceptual shadow-pictures you have the super-sensible reality just as little as in the shadow-picture of the hand you have the hand itself. Accordingly we have recognized here that the concepts are the boundary between the two realities, but originate from the super-sensible reality.

name: Anonymous
com: 200 Years Together is enlightening if you're interested in jews during the time of the Russian Empire and their role in the formation of the USSR, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you already have a grasp on the more general narrative of Russian history during that time. That's true for any study of a diaspora population since they're inherently in within the context of a broader history, but that's especially true for a work of this depth. That being said it's a book that can change your understanding of the jewish question permanently.

com:
>>17510492

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510478
As a form of sublimation- to deal with guilt, fucked up thoughts. I grew up Catholic so I've got a fair bit of that.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510478
You ask why I write, and I ask you, why do I shit and pee? It is for the same reason.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510478
Being a better writer translates into being a better reader, which makes you get better at thinking.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510478
I'm a tormented person. It is mainly to figure out a way to deal with it and avoiding being destroyed in the process.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510498
Changing my thoughts? It helps me find both redundancies and novelties in my thinking. It helps me to put things into words that I struggled to understand before.
The high of having created something I find good and getting praise for it wears off relatively quickly. So then, when re-reading once the high wore off I can see more clearly what is good and what is bad about my writing. I remember rereading a journal I kept in 2018 where the premise was that I would write an entry every day to kick-start myself into discipline and high achiever-dom. There was this weirdly sober but naive quality of confidence within it, which was then punctuated by entries that came about because I neglected to write for a few days or weeks. The entries that came after not doing it for some time were so angry and shameful but also cathartic. There's a few passages where I basically just insult myself for sentences on end.

Basically it helps me to git gudder

The Romantic Agony Gabe me a strange appreciation of how beauty is as much about our pain as our transcendence, that you must understand the uttermost depths of despair to create a beauty that alleviates it. Beauty is spiritually vital and innocent, a window to a higher truth that cannot be truly incarnated into form. And yet it is also uncanny and eerie, cryptically melancholic, animated with our spiritual wounds and pathological delusions.

>>17510828
Seems smart to someone ignorant but is in fact a psued argument. Even the most shallow dive into history reveals that emulating past trends and reviving old traditions and attempting to recapture some lost age imagined to be more enlightened is incredible common in all cultures throughout history. I mean, just look at how beards are popular among East Orthodox Christian priests whereas catholic priests are all clean shaven. It wasn’t always this way. Catholic priests started to normalize clean shaven faces in the early medieval as a way to recapture the Roman ideal, whereas beards were gradually seen as “eastern” and “alien” in priests. You've been given total control to redesign the American Literature education system.
How do you structure it?
What books will you have each grade read and why?
How will you determine the students' understanding of them, if at all?

name: Anonymous
com:
>total control to redesign American Literature education system
There would be different reading lists for Whites and Negroes. Whites would follow a pattern similar to currently, except with about 2-3x as many books per year, and everything shifted up a little, so that some wore advanced works can be read in high school, rather than saved for college (however, I do think that at such a young age, even with extensive education, one lacks the perspective and experience to really grasp certain works, so I don't want the curriculum to become needlessly advanced just so we can brag that in America high schoolers read Finnegan's Wake).
They would also be required to learn Ancient Greek and Latin to the extent necessary to read Homer and Virgil in the original. If the school wants to provide courses in those languages, great, but otherwise, it will simply be a requirement of the course and it is up to the students and their parents to figure out how best to learn the languages.

For Negro students, we would assign Huckleberry Finn, Heart of Darkness, etc., just maybe 5-6 books in total for their entire 12 years of schooling, and they'd be allowed to stop taking the course/subject as soon as they successfully explained the meaning behind the work and whether it is advocating for/against slavery, colonialism, etc. However, I'm worried this may cause graduation rates to drop even further.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17507432
K--2 - learning to read, mostly picture books
3-4 - "fun" books (Diary of a Wimpy kid, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, etc.)
5-6 - genre fiction and YA (Percy Jackson, Ender's game, The Hunger games, etc.)
7 - transition year, mixture of the previous and next years
8 - 9 - focus shifts to literary fiction and learning how to read critically, more focus on writing and grammar than on literature during these years
10-12 - English class optional after this point, Heavy focus on the cannon, intro to poetry and nonfiction

com:
whenever there are two opposing concepts in a hegelian system, they are the same thing in the sense that their content is the same but what you mean by them are different (they are only semantically different). neither could exist or be defined without the other so their coexistance creates both.

think of it as drawing a circle. you cant draw a circle without also creating a negative circle outside of that circle. but their content, whats inside that circle, is the same. they are only divided by the circle youve semantically drawn.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510500
Is this the same as zen non-duality?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17511020
in a way yes. there are many mystical interpretations of hegel. but since his system is almost exclusively focused on how those semantically created opposites interact, its closer to ying yang.

i guess he would be both a non dualist and a dualist, which is a very hegelian thing to be

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510500
one easy way to avoid this is to claim that assertion and compartmentalization is a necessary function of humanity in a participatory universe. in that way when you say this is a circle it confers on that part of reality a real distinction. and to further avoid the problems of this is to be at least a moderate realist about correspondence of mind to reality, since for there to be an account of circularity that we can agree upon, there must be a correspondence between our minds and that thing which we call circular in nature, were it not so, how could we agree that it is circular and have that as an abstract concept everyone understands? so i think one way to avoid this kind of thing is to create a participatory universe where assertion and distinction is simply built-in as hardware and to be a moderate realist by recognizing that there really must be some such thing in reality that we can all agree upon to call it circular.

sub: Intro to Philosophy Classes in University
com: Alright /lit/ I really want to know. What texts did you read in your intro to philosophy classes at your university? Or what texts do the profs teach, if you know separately from taking the classes yourself? In my experience in three different universities (not that I took the classes myself other than once, but I did know about them), every single one of those classes had some contemporary analytic readings. Some more than others, they were the majority in most. If that wasn't the case, then it was historical stuff. I never saw a class that offered continental philosophy in intro. What's your experience?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>17510384
Nah. I had a guy talking about orientierung, sich orientieren--to look for, to orientate; to search in a way for answers--and haltung--attitude or pose--which comes as a result of θαυμάζειν--thaumazein.
Really interesting and surprisingly continental ideas, but he was, and is I presume, a terrible lecturer : so if you didn't read his books or texts beforehand : took your handy adderall and listened to his single sentence paragraphs with a diamond focus--no powerpoint or visual aid, just a single page handout for a two hour lecture with quotes that weren't his own : -- you understood jackshit.

My introduction to logic was of course analytic and held by a nice but rather -- well standard uni stock guy, with a bunch of star wars and lotr references to offer examples for the propositional and predicate logic he talked about.

I guess it was a good introduction, but honestly I didn't pay much attention -- focussed on my other lectures in picked instead : lots of language and psychology.

name: Anonymous
com:

com: has anyone here been able to make a living writing?

name: Anonymous
com:
Yes, I am making a living as a freelance writer. My income is bolstered by manual labor and government benefits now and then, but I'm pretty much writing full time. It can be kind of maddening sometimes having to commodify your passion, being stuck with your thoughts all day every day, but I think I like to think I'm on the path to something better. I want to write fiction in the future, and I'd like if possible to transition into journalism, to get out in the world and work with real events and real people.

I don't know. Whatever you do life sucks. You have a dream for years and you achieve it and it sucks. If you're a writer write, it's probably going to suck.

That's an immature and overly-purist attitude. I don't view it as selling out so much as taking an apprenticeship. If I've got to do soul-crushing work anyways I might as well train the right muscles while I do it. Some people pay others for this kind of discipline and practice, and I'm paid for it instead. I've gotten more fiction writing done since going pro than I ever did before. I don't face things like "writer's block" now, I sit down and I write. Maybe success waits for me and maybe not. I'm getting older now. I have to work. This is the course of things.
